ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: an introduction to the basics of the editing and publication craft, and a working knowledge of the differences between the tasks of line and copy editors, fact checkers, and higher order editorial positions.

I learned practical skills in literary editing and practiced reading with the mindset of an editor. This course served as an introduction to different aspects of editing: line editing, fact checking, copy editing, working with structure and organization, and corresponding with writers during the editorial process. I was able to practice editing on sample pieces from The Yale Review and learn from professionals both at TYR and at other publications.

I learned more than I ever thought I could with Professor O'Rourke's guidance. Through readings, class discussions/group edits, and our incredible guests, I gained such a holistic understanding of editing.
Insight into the editorial process and practical editing skills

This class was my favorite by far this semester. It is likely my favorite English class so far at Yale. We were able to dive into very practical discussions about modes and methods of editing, and more broad and abstract discussions about the role of editors and the publishing industry. We did things like edit tests where we had to edit a piece of copy as an assignment and also had response papers to books on editing and publishing. It was simply a FANTASTIC class with so much to give!
Firsthand experience working with a magazine. How to do line edits and write notes to the author.

I developed a rich and practical understanding of different subfields and professional opportunities in publishing as well as both broader/philosophical and more "micro"/logistical components of editing! I knew I loved line editing and growing a piece through collaborative developmental editing and revision before taking this course, but this course really took that bud of excitement and helped me grow as an editor and thoughtful contributor to and consumer of print culture.
I learned a lot about the practice of editing, editing skills, and what makes a good editor.

Knowledge of many aspects of editing and what it means to be an editor! From line editing/macro editing of pieces to managing a small literary journal/magazine. Super interesting and varied assignments & readings

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: one of the strengths of the course was the exposure to so many career editors at various stages in their career. something that could have been improved was integrating students into the submittable system to further expose them to the inner workings of a literary magazine. this was not an issue at all for our course, however, since we still got to engage with reviewing at least one submission each week.

The breadth of the course was a strength: we learned both about the history of the little magazine and about the editorial work of literary magazines today, had both guests from different publications and coursework centered on The Yale Review. I also appreciated that the pieces we read at any point in the semester tended to be the pieces under consideration or in the editorial process at The Yale Review, so the discussions we had about them felt real and relevant.
The guests, Professor O'Rourke, and the assignments. The only improvement I can think of is that some classes were more effective than others because they depended on the guest speaker.
The course was very practicum oriented, which is great, it would have also been great to be more embedded into the workings of the Yale review for more experience

I loved. the diversity of the assignments and readingswhich spanned from reading actually Yale Review submissions to writing an Edit Memo about how to improve a magazine like the Paris Review. This class made me think so much about the role of publishers and editors, and also helped me become a better editor myself.
Strengths:  reading the yale review manuscripts and discussing them in class; meeting with all the different types of editors

Meghan did an amazing job organizing this course, especially considering the pandemic conditions! I think one strength is the diversity of perspectives we took/ modes and tasks we explored -- I loved starting the course with more theoretical consideration of the roles of an editor, editing as carework, the outdated model of iconic editor as exemplified by e.g. Gordon Lish, etc., and then moving into specific engagement with subfields like fact checking, copyediting, the final edit memo, audio, etc. I also really loved working with submissions to the Yale Review, and I feel that practical component really enriched the course.

I loved this courseit was both intellectually stimulating and useful, with opportunities to directly practice what we were learning about, and great guest speakers. I wish we would have had the chance to have been more involved with the Yale Review, but I think that will be easier in an in-person semester.
Really loved that we did hands-on work at the Yale Review and felt like we were contributing our ideas in a way that was both meaningful and educational

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had many speakers from the industry which was a definite plus
Overall the class was amazing!

I thought the seminar was surprisingly engaging for being in a virtual format, but it was tough to stay engaged for the entire two hours. Meghan was good about giving us a break partway through, which was helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes
Yes, if you have an interest in editing and are curious about what the day-to-day work of literary editing looks like.

YES!! Professor O'Rourke is incredible, and you learn so many skills through the (carefully considered) assignments. You also get to interact directly with numerous accomplished guest speakers. So cool.
Yes if they are interested in going into publishing.

I 10000000% recommend this course to anyone interested in writing, editing, publishing, or anything similar. This class will leave you with both practical editing skills and also more profound and abstract thoughts about the publishing industry and editors. I am taking away SO much from this class, and was so honored to be taught by Professor O'Rourke who is a simply legendary editor, thinker, and professor. I'm so glad that Prof. O'Rourke conceptualized and carried out this class. It's a MUST TAKE!

100% ! One of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale and, as a senior, a wonderful (and rare) opportunity to blend rigorous intellectual investigation with a specific and useful investigation of a particular professional industry. Any student with an interest in working in publishing postgrad should take this course, as well as anybody who simply enjoys editing -- another thing I loved about the course was the diversity of backgrounds, interests, and writing/editing extracurricular/professional experiences among the students drawn to the course.
If you are interested in the practice of editing, absolutely! The course was fantastic, and challenging in a fun way.
Absolutely! If you're interested in being a writer/editor/work in publishing take this course!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual office hours/one-on-one meetings
Virtual practicum editorial meetings
None
